categories.name: Data Center Basics
categories.description: Fundamental data center concepts and terminology

cards.definition: A data center facility where multiple companies rent space for their servers and equipment. Provides shared infrastructure including power, cooling, and connectivity.
cards.example: Equinix operates colocation facilities where companies can rent rack space instead of building their own data centers.

cards.definition: The raised-floor area in a data center where IT equipment (servers, storage, networking) is installed. Excludes support infrastructure like HVAC and electrical rooms.
cards.example: A 100,000 sq ft data center might have 60,000 sq ft of white space available for customer equipment.

cards.definition: The amount of power (measured in kilowatts or megawatts) that can be delivered per unit of space, typically measured in kW per rack or kW per square foot.
cards.example: Modern hyperscale data centers can support 15-20 kW per rack, while older facilities may only support 5-8 kW per rack.

cards.definition: A metric that measures data center efficiency by dividing total facility power by IT equipment power. A PUE of 1.0 is perfect efficiency; typical data centers have PUE of 1.2-1.8.
cards.example: If a data center uses 10 MW total and 7 MW goes to IT equipment, the PUE is 10÷7 = 1.43

cards.definition: Classification system (Tier I-IV) developed by Uptime Institute to rate data center availability and redundancy. Higher tiers indicate better uptime guarantees.
cards.example: Tier IV data centers guarantee 99.995% uptime (26 minutes downtime/year) vs Tier I at 99.671% (29 hours/year).

cards.definition: A system design where there is one extra component beyond the minimum required (N) to handle the load. Provides fault tolerance if one component fails.
cards.example: If 4 cooling units are needed to cool the facility, N+1 means installing 5 units so operations continue if one fails.

cards.definition: A system design with two fully independent systems, each capable of supporting 100% of the load. Provides higher availability than N+1.
cards.example: 2N power means two complete power paths from utility to IT equipment, each able to handle full load independently.

cards.definition: Data center layout where server racks face each other in alternating rows. Cold aisles face equipment air intakes, hot aisles face equipment exhaust.
cards.example: Cold aisles typically maintain 65-75°F while hot aisles can reach 90-110°F, improving cooling efficiency.

cards.definition: Elevated flooring system in data centers that creates a plenum (empty space) underneath for cooling air distribution and cable management.
cards.example: Typical raised floors are 18-36 inches high, allowing cool air to be pushed up through perforated floor tiles.

cards.definition: Computer Room Air Conditioner (CRAC) or Computer Room Air Handler (CRAH) - specialized cooling units designed for data center environments.
cards.example: CRAC units use refrigerant for cooling while CRAH units use chilled water, both specifically designed for 24/7/365 operation.

categories.name: Market Intelligence
categories.description: Data center market analysis and competitive intelligence terms

cards.definition: Massive data centers (typically 100+ MW, 250,000+ sq ft) built by cloud providers like AWS, Microsoft, Google for their own operations at unprecedented scale.
cards.example: AWS operates hyperscale data centers exceeding 1 million sq ft with 100+ MW of power capacity.

cards.definition: The amount of data center space leased or sold in a market during a specific period, indicating market demand.
cards.example: Northern Virginia absorbed 450 MW of data center capacity in 2024, the highest in the U.S.

cards.definition: Total data center capacity under construction or planned in a market. Critical indicator of future supply.
cards.example: Phoenix has 800 MW in pipeline (under construction) vs 600 MW of existing operational capacity.

cards.definition: Percentage of available data center space that is currently unleased. Lower vacancy indicates tighter market.
cards.example: Northern Virginia has <5% vacancy rate due to high demand from cloud providers.

cards.definition: Large-scale data center leases (typically full buildings or floors) to single tenants, as opposed to retail colocation (individual racks/cages).
cards.example: Digital Realty leases entire buildings (10-50 MW) to hyperscale customers as wholesale colocation.

cards.definition: Smaller data center leases to multiple tenants, selling space by the rack, cage, or suite. Higher revenue per MW than wholesale.
cards.example: Equinix provides retail colocation, selling individual racks or cages to hundreds of customers per facility.

cards.definition: Direct private network connections between customers within the same data center or between data centers, enabling low-latency data transfer.
cards.example: Equinix generates 40%+ of revenue from interconnection fees between customers in their facilities.

cards.definition: Smaller data centers (1-10 MW) located close to end users in secondary markets to reduce latency for applications.
cards.example: Edge data centers in cities like Omaha or Des Moines support low-latency gaming and streaming services.

cards.definition: Data center development where a facility is custom-designed and built specifically for a single tenant customer's requirements.
cards.example: CyrusOne built a 50 MW build-to-suit facility in Phoenix for an unnamed hyperscale customer.

cards.definition: The point at which a data center reaches its target occupancy level (typically 80-90%), indicating successful lease-up.
cards.example: A new 40 MW facility reaches stabilized occupancy when it leases 32-36 MW to customers.

categories.name: Infrastructure & Engineering
categories.description: Technical infrastructure components and engineering concepts

cards.definition: Battery-based system that provides immediate backup power during utility outages, bridging the gap until generators start (typically 10-15 seconds).
cards.example: A 10 MW data center might have 2 MW of UPS capacity providing 5-10 minutes of runtime.

cards.definition: Backup power generation equipment that starts automatically during extended utility outages. Typically 2N redundant in Tier III/IV facilities.
cards.example: Tier IV data centers maintain 96+ hours of diesel fuel on-site for continuous generator operation.

cards.definition: Equipment that distributes electrical power from UPS/generators to server racks. Can be rack-mounted or floor-standing units.
cards.example: A rack PDU might distribute 208V three-phase power to 42U of server equipment.

cards.definition: Large-scale cooling equipment that removes heat from data center cooling water loops. Can be air-cooled or water-cooled.
cards.example: A 10 MW data center might use 4-6 chillers, each with 1,000+ ton cooling capacity.

cards.definition: Equipment that uses evaporation to reject heat from chiller condensers to the atmosphere. Common in water-cooled chiller systems.
cards.example: Hyperscale data centers use massive cooling towers processing thousands of gallons per minute.

cards.definition: Cooling technique that uses outside air or water temperature to cool the facility when ambient conditions allow, reducing energy costs.
cards.example: Data centers in cold climates can achieve 8+ months of free cooling, significantly reducing PUE.

cards.definition: Direct cooling of servers using liquid (water or dielectric fluid) instead of air. Required for high-density AI/GPU workloads (30+ kW/rack).
cards.example: NVIDIA DGX systems with 8 H100 GPUs require liquid cooling to handle 10+ kW per server.

cards.definition: Unused fiber optic cable infrastructure available for lease. Tenants light their own equipment on the fiber for private networks.
cards.example: Data centers on dark fiber routes can offer customers private 100G+ connections between facilities.

cards.definition: Centralized location in a data center where telecom carriers and network providers interconnect, enabling customer carrier choice.
cards.example: Major carrier hotels have MMRs with 50+ carriers, providing diverse connectivity options.

cards.definition: On-site or nearby utility facility that transforms high-voltage power (69kV-230kV) to medium voltage (12-35kV) for data center use.
cards.example: Hyperscale campuses require dedicated utility substations delivering 100+ MW from the grid.

categories.name: Business & Finance
categories.description: Commercial real estate and financial terminology for data centers

cards.definition: Lease structure where tenant pays base rent plus property taxes, insurance, and maintenance (CAM). Common in wholesale data center leases.
cards.example: A 10 MW wholesale lease might be $110/kW/month base rent + $15/kW/month NNN charges.

cards.definition: Shared facility operating expenses (security, landscaping, common utilities) paid by tenants in addition to base rent.
cards.example: CAM charges might include 24/7 security, parking lot maintenance, and lobby operations.

cards.definition: Predictable monthly revenue from colocation customers. Key metric for data center REIT valuations.
cards.example: A retail colo facility with 500 racks at $2,000/month generates $1M MRR.

cards.definition: REIT financial metric measuring cash flow after capital expenditures. Used to value data center REITs and determine dividend capacity.
cards.example: Digital Realty's AFFO per share determines its quarterly dividend to shareholders.

cards.definition: Property valuation metric = Net Operating Income ÷ Property Value. Lower cap rates indicate more valuable assets.
cards.example: Stabilized data centers trade at 5-7% cap rates vs 7-9% for speculative developments.

cards.definition: Landlord contribution toward customer build-out costs (cages, racks, cable trays). Typically $50-150 per usable sq ft.
cards.example: A 10,000 sq ft lease might include $100/sq ft TIA ($1M) for customer infrastructure.

cards.definition: One-time and recurring charges for network connections between customers or to carriers. High-margin revenue for colo providers.
cards.example: A fiber cross-connect might cost $500 installation + $100/month recurring.

cards.definition: On-site technical support service where data center staff perform tasks on behalf of customers. Billed hourly or as monthly retainer.
cards.example: Remote hands services charge $150-250/hour for tasks like rebooting servers or swapping drives.

cards.definition: Contractual guarantee of uptime percentage and performance. Violations typically result in service credits.
cards.example: A 99.999% SLA allows only 5.26 minutes of downtime per year; violations might credit 10-25% of monthly fees.

cards.definition: Securing tenant commitments before data center construction begins. Reduces development risk and improves financing terms.
cards.example: Developers typically require 40-60% pre-leasing before breaking ground on speculative builds.

categories.name: Compliance & Security
categories.description: Security certifications and regulatory compliance requirements

cards.definition: Auditing standard verifying a service organization's security, availability, and confidentiality controls over a 6-12 month period.
cards.example: Enterprise customers require SOC 2 Type II reports before placing sensitive workloads in colocation.

cards.definition: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard - security requirements for handling credit card data. Requires specific physical and network controls.
cards.example: Financial services companies require PCI DSS compliant cages/suites for payment processing systems.

cards.definition: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act - regulations protecting healthcare data privacy and security.
cards.example: Healthcare providers require HIPAA-compliant data centers with access controls and audit logging.

cards.definition: Federal Information Security Management Act - security framework for U.S. government systems and contractors.
cards.example: Government cloud providers need FISMA High data centers for classified/sensitive government workloads.

cards.definition: International standard for information security management systems (ISMS). Demonstrates systematic approach to security.
cards.example: Global enterprises often require ISO 27001 certification for data centers housing international operations.

cards.definition: Two-door security vestibule where only one door can open at a time, preventing tailgating and ensuring one-person-at-a-time access.
cards.example: Tier III+ data centers use mantraps with biometric + card access controlling entry to white space.

cards.definition: Statement on Standards for Attestation Engagements - framework for SOC reports. Replaced older SSAE 16 standard.
cards.example: Annual SSAE 18 SOC 2 audits verify data center controls meet customer security requirements.

cards.definition: Protection against voltage spikes and surges that could damage sensitive IT equipment. Required for high-availability facilities.
cards.example: TVSS systems protect against lightning strikes and utility switching transients.

cards.definition: Security systems using physical characteristics (fingerprint, iris, palm vein) for authentication. Common in high-security data centers.
cards.example: Financial services data centers often require fingerprint + card + PIN for cage access.

cards.definition: Clean agent fire suppression gases that extinguish fires without damaging electronics or leaving residue. Preferred over water sprinklers in white space.
cards.example: FM-200 systems deploy within 10 seconds of smoke detection, suppressing fire before water sprinklers activate.
